data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: New Colonialism
data.desc:
In recent years, artificial intelligence has emerged as a transformative force in many fields, such as content moderation and automation. 
However, as recent research shows, when these systems are predominantly designed according to Western paradigms, several issues arise that go beyond technical errors: they are systemic flaws that can harm already marginalized communities.

data.title: The Limits of Automated Moderation in Minoritized Languages
data.desc: Study showing how automated moderation systems (AI/algorithms) fail or are biased when applied to languages with poor digital support. For example, Quechua, an indigenous South American language, can be misinterpreted or ignored.

data.title: Cognitive Imperialism and AI Failure
data.desc: While AI drives transformation, its development primarily follows Western paradigms, often ignoring Indigenous knowledge systems. This oversight is a form of cognitive imperialism, which perpetuates biases and limits the creation of truly inclusive AI. Consequently, AI systems frequently misinterpret Indigenous realities, leading to culturally insensitive or harmful solutions. Closing this gap is crucial for building universally reliable and ethical AI technology.

data.title: Integrating Indigenous Knowledge to Decolonize AI
data.desc: An innovative methodology has been proposed to integrate Indigenous knowledge systems into AI development, aiming to counteract cognitive imperialism and bias. The framework is participatory, drawing on AI ethics, postcolonial studies, and Indigenous knowledge. It involves co-creation, ethical data protocols, and algorithmic adaptation. Demonstrated through case studies (NLP, content moderation, and healthcare), the approach provides a concrete method to "decolonize" AI and promote equity and cultural respect.

data.title: Techno-Linguistic Bias and Epistemic Injustice in AI
data.desc: AI language technologies cover very few of the world's languages. Efforts to include "underserved" languages often lead to solutions plagued by techno-linguistic bias. This bias prioritizes the concepts and structures of dominant languages in system design, resulting in the misrepresentation of marginalized cultures and communities. The authors frame this as epistemic injustice, highlighting that this reductive approach excludes the unique needs and worldviews of many linguistic communities, with real socio-political consequences.

data.title: Indigenous Data Sovereignty: A Response to Algorithmic Exclusion
data.desc: Indigenous communities suffer more harm than benefit from algorithms and do not participate in their design. To react, they have developed the concept of Indigenous Data Sovereignty (IDS), which is the right to manage their own data according to their own laws and cultures. A concrete example is Māori Data Sovereignty in New Zealand, which has generated models for data use that is respectful of Māori culture.

data.title: Decolonizing Data: Indigenous Sovereignty and the CARE Principles
data.desc: The research criticizes data mining for replicating colonial logic and excluding Indigenous voices in AI development. It calls for recognizing Indigenous Data Sovereignty and using the CARE Principles (Collective Benefit, Authority to Control, Responsibility, and Ethics) as a framework. Case studies show that proper data governance protects both Indigenous communities and environmental ecosystems, proposing an ethical development model that prioritizes justice over profit.

data.title: Badjao Tribe
data.desc:
The Badjao, an Austronesian population spanning the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia, don't simply live near the sea, they embody a true aquatic culture.
For them, water is neither a boundary nor a resource, but a living space and a place of belonging. This concept permeates every aspect of their existence: identity, religion, knowledge, physicality, and socioeconomic organization.

data.title: Sanguma
data.desc:
The Sanguma violence in Papua New Guinea is a cultural crisis caused by the failure of modern institutions (medicine, economy).

Poverty and frustration are channeled into belief in magic, turning structural issues into supernatural conflicts. This targets vulnerable women as scapegoats, creating a power vacuum where community justice (kastom) overrides state law.

This aggression, especially in the Chimbu Highlands, is the symptom of a clash of authority in a rapidly changing society.

data.title: Facial Recognition Bias: Misclassifying Dark-Skinned Women
data.desc:
A study shows that the most common datasets used to train these systems, IJB-A and Adiencesono, are composed of subjects with light skin by 79.6% and 86.2% respectively.
For this reason, the Gender Shades project tested three major commercial facial recognition systems (Microsoft, IBM, and Face++), finding that the most misclassified category was darker-skinned women, with error rates exceeding 30%, while errors for light-skinned men were almost non-existent.

data.title: Indigenous Knowledge Exclusion in Marine Conservation
data.desc:
The Badjao's animistic worldview and symbiotic relationship with the sea are dismissed as primitive and unscientific. Their knowledge is ignored, and their fishing methods are often banned.

Specific top-down conservation policies have been created that exclude the Badjao from the planning and management of Marine Protected Areas, failing to recognize their historical role as environmental stewards.

data.title: Modern witch hunts
data.desc:
Modern witch hunts are not relics of the past but a persistent crisis in regions like Papua New Guinea, Sub-Saharan Africa, and parts of India.

This violence is a symptom of failing modern institutions (medicine, economy, law). When structural issues like poverty or unexplained sicknesses lack rational explanation, the frustration is channeled into belief in sorcery. Vulnerable individuals—often older women or widows—are identified as scapegoats by local diviners for profit.

This mechanism replaces state authority with supernatural conflict, allowing community-sanctioned torture and murder to continue where the legal system is absent or distrusted.

The Scientific American video highlights that the severe violence and fear surrounding witchcraft accusations (SARV) in Papua New Guinea are rooted in a lack of scientific explanation for misfortune, sickness, and death.

The solution being explored involves public health initiatives and science education to combat deep-seated beliefs. By providing reliable, verifiable explanations for common diseases (like malaria or typhoid), proponents aim to dismantle the necessity of blaming innocent individuals (often women and children) and reduce the authority of sorcery beliefs in favor of scientific and biomedical understanding.

data.title: PNG Criminalizes Sorcery Accusation Violence (SARV)
data.desc:
In February 2022, the Papua New Guinea Parliament passed key amendments to the Criminal Code aimed at combating the rising scourge of violence related to sorcery accusations (SARV).

The new legislation takes a bold step by formally criminalizing SARV and specifically targeting the glasman and glasmeri (diviners or witch-finders) who are paid to identify alleged sorcerers, often resulting in the torture, rape, and murder of vulnerable women and children.

data.title: Children as Scapegoats in Modern Witch Hunts
data.desc:
In places like Papua New Guinea and parts of Africa, children are increasingly targeted and accused of being "child witches" or sorcerers.

When communities face unexplained tragedies (sickness, death, or financial ruin), diviners often pinpoint the most vulnerable individuals as scapegoats for profit. These victims are typically orphans, disabled children, or those from marginalized families.

data.title: Ghana's Witch Camps: Exile for the Elderly
data.desc:
In Ghana, hundreds of elderly women are accused of witchcraft, often due to poverty, land disputes, or unaddressed health issues (e.g., lack of scientific understanding of disease).

Forced out of their communities, these survivors seek refuge in informal "witch camps." Conditions there are dire, lacking electricity, adequate housing, and social welfare programs.

Many women, unable to work, are abandoned by their families and charities, leading them to die of hunger, disease, and neglect. Activists emphasize that the key to ending this crisis is not closing the camps, but tackling and ending the witchcraft accusations in the communities themselves.

data.title: What if the only way for preservation was "Cultural Cryopreservation"?
data.desc:
What happens when assimilation is so aggressive that the only way to save a culture is to "freeze" it and secure it? Inspired by the Badjao who might "retreat" to the sea, the custodians of at-risk cultures make a radical move: they create living time capsules. These are not digital archives, but physical, voluntarily isolated enclaves.

Universal experience: an international agreement grants a people like the Kurds or Tibetans the right to preserve their culture intact in a closed "sanctuary-territory," an autonomous area that voluntarily refuses any external contact for the next 200 years. Inside, the culture develops according to its own rules, without outside influences.

data.title: And what if culture became a sovereign diplomatic currency?
data.desc:
What if a people, instead of seeking political recognition, began to negotiate their culture directly as a tradable asset with other global actors (corporations, city-states, transnational organizations), completely bypassing the nation-states that oppress them?

Significance: Culture ceases to be a cause for marginalization and becomes a strategic asset.

data.title: what if unrecognized peoples became "citizens of time" instead of space?
data.desc: What if the answer to the lack of territory was not to seek a new space, but to reject the dominant temporality? What would happen if these peoples declared their allegiance to a different cultural timeline, creating temporal enclaves where their laws and traditions are sovereign? This is an act of civil disobedience that doesn't block roads, but suspends the dominant calendar, replacing it with their own biological, cultural, and cosmological rhythms.

data.title: Moodboard
data.desc: Option 1

data.title: Cyclical Time vs Linear Time
data.desc:
Cyclical time (minorities) vs. Linear time (profit and mass culture) → Cyclical time is the time of nature and memory.
ㅤ
This is a reconfiguration of power. While States control space, peoples without territory could control meaningful time—transforming their cyclical traditions into tools of sovereignty. They would force the world to synchronize with their cultural rhythms instead of succumbing to the linear time of forced progress. It is an act of self-determination that completely bypasses the logics of territorial control, shifting the conflict to a plane where indigenous peoples hold an insurmountable advantage: the authenticity of their relationship with natural and cultural cycles.

data.title: The Veneration of Robots
data.desc:
What if the answer to the identity vacuum wasn't the search for a new figure, but the rejection of dominant celebrity culture? What would happen if people elected digital figures as their own deities, creating communities where their digital figures and associated traditions are sacred?

The time of consumption, imposed by mass culture, pushes us to worship celebrities who follow the linear rhythm of success and fame. Sacred time, conversely, becomes the time of these digital figures, revered based on cycles of creation, interaction, and sharing within a community, rather than a rigid marketing plan.

This represents a reconfiguration of power. While the media and entertainment industry control the space of celebrity, people without an industry behind them could control meaningful time, transforming their own digital figures into tools of sovereignty. They would force the dominant culture to synchronize with their rhythms of worship, rather than forcing them to submit to the linear time of manufactured success.

data.title: Robot Priest in a Buddhist Temple in Kyoto
data.desc:
In Japan, the fusion of religion and technology already has a face: Mindar, a six-foot humanoid robot that delivers sermons at a 400-year-old Buddhist temple in Kyoto.

Mindar does not replace the human priest, but is seen as a means to make Buddhist teachings more accessible, demonstrating veneration not for the robot itself, but for its ability to embody and disseminate ancient wisdom in a new, technological form.

data.title: The Web3 Theologian
data.desc:
Vitalik Buterin, the co-creator of Ethereum, is not just a programmer, but a genuine philosopher and thinker of the digital world. His writings and reflections are not limited to the technical aspects of blockchain, but explore the ethical, social, and political implications of a decentralized network.

He is viewed as a spiritual guide and a point of reference for the entire Web3 movement, and his authority derives not from conventional fame, but from the depth of his thought.

data.title: Virtual Idol: Miku
data.desc: Hatsune Miku is a figure created by Crypton Future Media. She is not just a character, but an actual software (Vocaloid) with which people can create music and lyrics. Miku has become a global icon, with concerts where she performs as a hologram and a huge fan community that venerates her as a genuine pop star. Her fame is based on a collaborative and decentralized model, rather than on a single figure of power.

data.title: The Ethics of Building a Love Machine
data.desc: The document, titled "Robots, Love, and Sex: The Ethics of Building a Love Machine," explores the ethical implications of using affective computing in robotics to simulate human emotions like love and attraction, with the goal of creating artificial companions. The author argues that, although it is possible to build machines that induce humans to feel affection, the principles of machine ethics must be applied to establish limits on the manipulation of human psychology.

data.title: First 'Wrongful Death' Lawsuit Against AI
data.desc: United States: 14-Year-Old Boy Dies by Suicide After 'Falling in Love' with Chatbot; Mother Sues Company

data.title: False Arrests and Racial Bias in Facial Recognition
data.desc: The implications of this bias are very serious. In the United States, several documented cases have shown that law enforcement's use of facial recognition software has led to false arrests and indictments of people of color due to identification errors.

data.title: What if a terrorist entity arose whose operations relied solely on individuals not recognized by ai?
Stateless at Sea, Trespassers on Land
data.desc: As a stateless people of the sea, the Badjao become invisible to nation-states. Modern maritime laws criminalize their traditional lifestyle, transforming them from original inhabitants into trespassers.

data.title: From Sea Nomads to Sedentary Settlers
data.desc: The Sama-Bajau are being forced to abandon their traditional nomadic life on the sea due to ecological collapse (from industrial fishing and climate change) and legal/political pressures (national borders and sedentarization programs). Stripped of their livelihood and cultural identity, this stateless population is pushed into coastal settlements, where they face social discrimination and statelessness, criminalizing their ancient way of life and causing cultural disintegration.

The ecological collapse resulting from industrial fishing and pollution is destroying the Badjao’s marine habitat, stripping them of both food and identity. They are often forcibly resettled on land in “relocation villages,” severing their connection to the sea and disintegrating their culture.
links: Daug, Artchil C., Christopher O. Kimilat, Glory Grace Ann G. Bayon, e Angenel Clariz D. Rufon. "THE POSSIBILITY OF ETHNOGENESIS OF THE BADJAO IN BARANGAY TAMBACAN, ILIGAN CITY." Unpublished manuscript. Department of History, Mindanao State University-Iligan Institute of Technology

data.title: What if the only solution to preserve their culture was to detach themselves from the rest of the world, moving permanently into the sea?
Moodboard
data.desc: Option 2

data.title: Svalbard Global Seed Vault
data.desc:
Backup facility for the world's crop diversity. 
The Seed Vault provides long-term storage for duplicates of seeds from around the world, conserved in gene banks. This provides security of the world's food supply against the loss of seeds in genebanks due to mismanagement, accident, equipment failures, funding cuts, war, sabotage, disease, and natural disasters.

data.title: The Badjao Initiative: Trading Expertise for Survival
data.desc:
The Badjao, weary of state inaction, declare their culture an Endangered Living Heritage of Humanity and begin to sell it. They don't sell objects, but unique cultural services:

"Badjao Ecological Consulting" for major environmental NGOs, based on their millennial knowledge of marine ecosystems.

"Intellectual Access Rights" to their stellar navigation system for shipping companies interested in more efficient routes.

data.title: Global Culture Brokerage: Universal Examples
data.desc: Tibetans could negotiate the rights to their traditional medicine with pharmaceutical companies. Native Americans could sell land management services to states affected by wildfires.

data.title: What if the State, failing to defeat superstition, decided to create an infallible system based on those beliefs to re-establish control?
What if the community codified the evil of Sanguma into electronic waste, exiling the object instead of the accused witch?
